titleStmt.title: [University of Chicago Library GMS-0951, a manuscript catalogue description in electronic form]
titleStmt.funder: Institute of Museum and Library Services

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center

overview.p: Four gospels in Armenian. Eusebian section numbers in the margins against the text. Concordance numbers in the lower margins. Pentecostal lection numbers in the gospel of Matthew. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Arm. 48.
Full-page portraits of the Evangelists Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John. Marginal vignettes of birds, arabesques, and flowers.

headpieces.p: Headpieces of multi-colored floral, geometric, and foliate design at gospel openings (fols. 10r, 85r, 135r, 216r). The headpiece of Matthew's gospel contains small portraits of Christ's ancestors in circular frames.

initials.p: The major initial of each gospel's opening line is formed by an Evangelist symbol: Matthew (angel, 43 mm), Mark (lion, 26 mm), Luke (ox, 62 mm), and John (eagle, 51 mm). Minor initials are formed by figures of birds.

physDesc.extent: 284 leaves, of which 2 are flyleaves formed from a leaf of an older manuscript whose text was written in erkat’agir script.

foliation.p: 1 (unfoliated parchment flyleaf) + 282 + 1 (unfoliated parchment flyleaf). Modern foliation in Arabic numerals in pencil 1-282.

collation.p: 23 numbered quires. The first seven leaves containing the index and preface of Matthew are paper replacements.

physDesc.dimensions: Written space 85 x 60 mm (fol. 23r). Each column is 85 x 25 mm with a space of 10 mm between.

handDesc.p: Written in bolorgir script in black ink. The first line of each gospel is written in bird letters; the second line is rendered in erkat’agir script.

condition.p: The first seven leaves are detached from the binding.

binding.p: Leather over boards, covered with hammered silver. Spine and fore-edge flap of linen studded with rosettes of silver. Leather strap closures (one remaining). Doublures of floral-patterned linen. Remains of thread tabs.

decoNote.p: Front cover: Crucifixion of Christ with the Virgin Mary and John the Apostle on either side. Skull at base of cross; a seraph at each corner of the scene. Floral border and background. Back cover: Image of enthroned Virgin and Christ-child, within border engraved with prayer and date, O blessed Virgin Mother of the only-begotten. Intercede for me with the immortal king. In the year 1108 (1659).

origin.p: The manuscript was completed in 1661 (Armenian Era 1110) by the scribe Vardan, its place of origin unknown (his colophon, fol. 280v).

provenance.p: Late 17th to early 20th century provenance unknown. Belonged to book collector the Reverend Roderick Terry (1849-1933), of Newport, Rhode Island (his bookplate, front pastedown). The manuscript was sold at his estate sale in February 1935 by American Art Association-Anderson Galleries.

acquisition.p: Acquired by the University of Chicago from Mihran Costikyan of New York, September 1941.

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.
